author: Andreas
message:
I have my doubts that it's a good idea to add sundry image editing to a viewer like Gwenview. It is a viewer after all. Rotating seems to make sense because, from experience, on needs to rotate images all the time and also while viewing. Anything else, not so much.
It's a bit stupid that I only comment when I don't like something, so don't be put off. I still like Gwenview :)

author: teezee
message:
niiiiiiiceeee!

But go for smart recognition please, its so much more comfortable. And integrate it somewhere easier accessible.

author: Aurélien
message:
@Andreas: The idea is to make very basic picture manipulation options accessible. You can still use it as a viewer, it won't get in the way.

@Teezee: Smart recognition may happen later, I have other stuff to implement before feature freeze :). As for making it more accessible, it's also accessible from the sidebar, but I hid it in the screencast to accomodate with the limited video resolution.

author: Tyler
message:
The feature itself may be useful, it avoids to open the gimp.
Picasa has a function for correcting red eyes, so having it in gwenview too is cool.

author: Skaz!
message: I personnaly think thats a real great idea, keep going this way !

author: kwilliam
message: The title got me excited but the video is a disappointment. Why not re-use Digikam's red-eye removal algorithm? It's a much easier in my experience. Although, what we REALLY need it to get Google to open source Picasa's red eye removal tool, which is truly amazing!!

author: kwilliam
message: Btw, KDE4 Gwenview is REALLY AMAZING!! I love it. Used it for cropping some photos and rotating, and the slideshow mode is awesome - it's just a great program now! It was OK in KDE3, but it's really useful in KDE4 - I use it instead of Digikam for simple things now.

author: Aurélien
message: @kwilliam: you are right, I am going to check Digikam algorithm.

author: TheGrudge
